content: Southeast Asian traditional dessert and breakfast dish **Bubur cha cha**, also spelled as **bubur cha-cha** or **dubo jiajie**, is a [Betawi](/wiki/Betawi_cuisine) and [Malay](/wiki/Malay_cuisine) dessert and breakfast dish in [Indonesian cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine), [Malaysian cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine), [Singaporean cuisine](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) and [Phuket cuisine](/wiki/Phuket_cuisine) (Thailand) prepared using pearled [sago](/wiki/Sago), sweet potatoes, yams, bananas, coconut milk, [pandan](/wiki/Pandanus_amaryllifolius) leaves, sugar and salt. Grated coconut, coconut cream and water can be used as additional ingredients. The ingredients are cooked in coconut milk, and the dish can be served hot or cold. Bubur cha cha is also sold as a [street food](/wiki/Street_food) in many parts of Southeast Asia.[a] - Food portal - Indonesia portal - Malaysia portal - Singapore portal - Thailand portal - [Indonesian cuisine](/wiki/Indonesian_cuisine) - [Malaysian cuisine](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) - [Phuket cuisine](/wiki/Phuket_cuisine) - [Singaporean cuisine](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) - [Thai cuisine](/wiki/Thai_cuisine) - [List of desserts](/wiki/List_of_desserts) - [Betawi cuisine](/wiki/Betawi_cuisine) - [Malay cuisine](/wiki/Malay_cuisine) - [Peranakan cuisine](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine) - [Bubur kacang hijau](/wiki/Bubur_kacang_hijau) - [Bubur ketan hitam](/wiki/Bubur_ketan_hitam) - [Bubur pedas](/wiki/Bubur_pedas) - Bubur sumsum ## Notes - Bubur cha cha. Rotinrice.com.
title: Bubur cha cha
